Feb 25: "Oscar flashback: How close were 'Birdman' & 'Boyhood,' '12 Years a Slave' & 'Gravity,' 'The Hurt Locker' & 'Avatar'?" --> http://www.goldderby.com/news/11852/oscar-predictions-best-picture-the-revenant-the-big-short-spotlight-analysis-13579086.html In a previous article, I established an expansive theory which revolved around mathematics and statistics. Now that everything has been revealed, we have our final numbers. “Spotlight” has 21 boxes ticked off, “The Big Short” has 22 and “The Revenant” has the most, with 23. Yes, I predicted that “The Big Short” would get the most boxes ticked off and yes, because of that I predicted that it would win Best Picture at the Oscars. BUT, although that prediction was wrong, my theory of ‘whichever film ticks of the most boxes will win Best Picture’ is still on course to be proven right... as long as “The Revenant” wins big at the Oscars. But that does not mean “The Big Short” or “Spotlight” comes away as a loser yet, as this season has given us the most intense rivalry with the closest battle to be crowned top dog since I can remember. Therefore, I’ve decided to take three great rivalries and examine them under my ’35 boxes’ research and theory, hopefully learning something about this year’s race in return.  2014: “Birdman” vs “Boyhood”
2013: “12 Years A Slave” vs “Gravity”
2009: “The Hurt Locker” vs “Avatar” So, what does all of this mean? Firstly, I believe it may mean that “Birdman,” was lucky to win. “Boyhood” ticks six more boxes then “Birdman." Even if we take away those Golden Globes boxes, as some people like to do, then “Boyhood” is still five ahead. We could say that certain boxes mean more then others (PGA WIN over Golden Globe Acting Nomination for example) but the reason I created this style of research and this article with these 35 boxes is to be as expansive as possible across the board, not to designate importance. It’s a statistical, mathematical way of looking at the Oscar race, devoid of all the usual ‘this tea leaf means more’ stuff that we Escapologists (that’s a word, right?) love to dwell in. And here, in what is the exception to my theory and the rule of ‘the most boxes ticked wins,’ I believe that it shows “Birdman”’s Best Picture victory to be an upset. I won’t go so far as to say it was a mistake (“Birdman,” is a great film, after all), but those numbers would suggest that. “Boyhood” was number one from the very beginning of the season (practically since Sundance that year) and my gut instinct is that it peaked too early and people perhaps became bored of it, fed up of hearing about it and enjoyed the fresh, late arrival of “Birdman” and so wanted to enjoy this ‘new toy’ on the scene. And that late surge hushed “Boyhood” and was enough for “Birdman” to sneak the win. A very close race, but “Birdman”’s late, ‘new toy’ quality gave it that edge. “12 Years A Slave,” however, performs much better over it’s rival, “Gravity,” as it pulled ahead by five boxes. Although “Gravity” did have a lot of support, prevailing at the DGA and PGA, “12 Years A Slave” had that oh-so-important universal love (crucial to winning Best Picture because of the preferential ballot), doing well across the board. So, it wasn’t a barnstormer by Steve McQueen’s drama, but “12 Years A Slave,” with all that concrete support in all the key areas (directing, acting, writing, editing) and at all the right places, gave it a fairly easy ride in the end. “Gravity” gave it a good go, though. In the third rivalry there really is a rout, with “The Hurt Locker” ticking off a whopping 13 more boxes then “Avatar.” Although “Avatar” was said to be a fierce competitor to Kathryn Bigelow’s war drama at the time, on closer inspection it is blown out of the water and blown out of Pandora along with all that Unobtanium (wow, what a clever, imaginative name for something that is hard to obtain!.) Indeed, “Avatar”’s lack of acting and writing prowess across nearly all of the categories exposes that crucial weakness. “The Hurt Locker” had both across all 35 boxes, along with the guild support and a lot of love for director Bigelow. So, on closer inspection, this race was not as close as we once thought. Now, this is all very well and good, but what does it mean for this year’s Oscar race?
Because this year is a three-horse race as opposed to the above years’ two-horse races, it is a little tougher to draw comparisons from. However (as previously mentioned), after the BAFTAS, which were the final few boxes of the 35 to be revealed, “Spotlight”’s final total comes in at 21, “The Big Short”’s at 22 and “The Revenant” at 23. All of these films have been on the same page pretty much right from the off, garnering equal, consistent support across the board - so there won’t be a “Birdman/Boyhood” situation this year. Nor will we have an “Avatar/The Hurt Locker” situation; none of the three films have managed to pull ahead the way “The Hurt Locker” did. So, the rivalry from which we can learn the most is “12 Years A Slave” versus “Gravity.” Even though this year’s race is a much closer one then McQueen’s period drama vs Cuaron’s space thriller, both those films had splits and both had their strengths and weaknesses just like this year's trio. So, in relation to the above research, let’s take a look at how this year’s films fit into the mould of the “12 Years A Slave/Gravity” rivalry and see who is the likely runner(s) up and winner. It’s worth mentioning that due to the close nature of our race this year, the words ‘winner’ and ‘runner up’ have often become muddled for all three films. “The Big Short”
Like “Gravity,” Adam McKay’s ‘traumedy,’ as he calls it, prevailed at PGA. However like Cuaron’s space-flick, it failed to win Best Picture at the Golden Globes, the Critic’s Choice awards and the BAFTAS. Both films won zilch at SAG, too.
But comparisons can also be made with “12 Years A Slave.” Both films got consistent support across the board for the key four elements; directing, acting, writing and editing - plus the corresponding nominations at the Oscars. So “The Big Short” is stuck somewhere in between these two films, which is proven by it’s numbers; it got 22 total boxes ticked off, while “Gravity” got 20 and “12 Years A Slave” got 25. Almost slap bang in the middle of the two. It’s better then a runner up but, I’m afraid, it’s not quite good enough to be a winner. With just a tad more support, I could be saying roll on the Academy Awards for the “Anchorman” anchor and his traumedy masterpiece. “Spotlight”
Tom McCarthy’s restrained, journalist-drama has fallen behind. Although it won at Critic’s Choice, as “12 Years A Slave” did, it came away from the Golden Globes empty-handed and struggled at the BAFTAS, unlike “12 Years A Slave.”
Furthermore, “Spotlight” has failed to earn any consistent acting and directing support, both of which “Gravity” and “12 Years A Slave” had in abundance. It has also fared poorly with the guilds, with it’s only triumph coming at SAG for Best Ensemble. Of all the guilds, that award is probably the least accurate tea leaf; only six of the last 10 Best Ensemble winners have gone on to win Best Picture. Heck, “American Hustle” won Best Ensemble in 2013 and later got blanked at the Academy Awards. Indeed, “Spotlight,” with only it’s screenplay providing it with any consolation, is falling into the mould of “Gravity” and into the mould of runner up, if that. “The Revenant”
Inarritu’s western also draws similarities between both films. It’s got three out of the four key Oscar nominations in directing, acting and editing, the exact same as “Gravity,” and both films won at DGA. Similarly to “12 Years A Slave,” it won at SAG, won the top prize at the Golden Globes and BAFTA (both films also got a Best Actor win at the latter as well) and got consistent support across the entire board. It does have one weakness, though... it’s writing. As mentioned time and again, screenwriters Inarritu and Mark L. Smith have failed to crop up anywhere on the circuit. But the key thing here is that “The Revenant,” like “12 Years A Slave,” has the most boxes ticked out of the 35. The former has 23, while the latter has 25. That final stat is the one that sticks with me. Like Daniel Montgomery, I too like to stick to stats and math when it comes to predicting and try my best to avoid emotion-predicting. I have gone on record stating that I have faith in my theory and, like my theory states, ‘the film with the most boxes ticked will win Best Picture.’ All of the 35 boxes have now been revealed. Time is up and I’m staying faithful to my theory and faithful to math.  ~~~~~~~ COMMENT: Man, I wish I hadn't thrown so much shade at REV at the beginning of this IFP (it's partly why I've got it so high right now). Ok, so I've done further research and I'm updating my forecast. God it is hard to predict the winning picture in such an unusual year...  So the race is clearly between 3 movies, and here is my updated rationale for each one of them. Revenant: Revenant has gained a lot of momentum since its win at BAFTAs, that's why I'm increasing its probability to 30%. Not to mention it is the one with more nominations (12). Historically, when a picture has 12 or more nominations, it wins the award. However, only 3 movies have won the Oscar without a screenplay nomination in the last 75 years (Titanic, The sound of music, Hamlet). Moreover, I believe that the British Academy somewhat made it up to Iñárritu for not giving the award last year (lost to Boyhood and Linklater), and the other two serious contenders were clearly American subjects which are not as attractive to the British critics as Nature vs Man. In addition, Revenant won the DGA award, which predicts the winning director about 90% of the times and the 80% of the times for the film. Personally, it was my favorite movie, I really hope it wins, but statistics are something that I just can't ignore. Spotlight: Spotlight was snubbed at Editing and Directing at BAFTAs and American Cinema Editors Awards (ACE), two major categories it would need to win in order to take the best picture award home. Actors loved the film, and also did journalists, but not all of them will vote for the Academy Awards. Spotlight won the SAG, but, sadly for them, this is the lowest success rate predictor of all Guild awards. So I believe Revenant managed to catch up with Spotlight, and its chances for winning the Oscar are now better than ever. The Big Short: So, out of these films, this one I liked the least (not that I didn't enjoy it). However, as I mentioned earlier, hard data is something I find really difficult to ignore. Big Short won the PGA, and as I contemplated in all my previous forecasts, it has aligned (100%) with the Academy award ever since they have the same 'preferential ballot' voting system. Both systems have around 7,000 voters, which should add statistical significance to the PGA. In addition, it is the only film to hit the big four nominations beside Spotlight (Directing, Actor, Editing, Screenplay), and the only best picture nominee other than Spotlight to have a SAG cast nomination. It is the ONLY nominee to hit all five major guild nominations and all five BAFTA nominations. Not only that, but it won a three of the most critical guild awards: Producers, Writers and Editors.  I probably have a poor taste in cinema, however, I'm sticking to the numbers here. Personally, I'd rather have Revenant taking the Oscar, but I think it is best if I stick to the numbers and have a pleasant surprise if it goes the other way.  Anything can happen its a very unusual year for the Academy Awards.

Feb 19: "'The Revenant' is ahead by a nose" --> https://www.intelligentlifemagazine.com/culture/the-daily/the-revenant-is-ahead-by-a-nose The race for the Best Picture Oscar is all over the place this year. Pundits always say that, having a professional interest in making the race sound closer than it is. But this year it really is close, with all the preceding awards which normally foretell Oscar glory going in completely different directions. Tom McCarthy’s sexual-abuse exposé “Spotlight” was the front-runner for a long time, picking up the acting-ensemble award from the Screen Acting Guild – until its momentum was stolen by Adam McKay’s “The Big Short”. This film about the Wall Street meltdown won Best Drama at the Producers Guild of America (PGA), and who would bet against them? Except the Golden Globes and the BAFTAs, which earlier this week gave the Best Film, Director, Cinematography and Actor awards to Alejandro Gonzalez Iñárritu’s brutal, beautiful Western, “The Revenant”.  Iñárritu picked up an Oscar for “Birdman” last year and he could well be about to win again, making him the first director since John Ford to accomplish back-to-back wins. Never underestimate the Academy’s desire to make history. Nobody likes a sweep more than them. There are few things more satisfying – or simpler – than going down that list of boxes, checking the same film for Editing, Best Picture, Directing, Screenplay. It looks crisp, decisive, unassailable. It’s a rare Best Picture winner that doesn’t also win for Editing, regardless of whether it happens to be the best-edited film or not (was “Argo”?). No film has won Best Picture without also winning for its script since “Titanic”; and auteurists get hot and bothered when films win without their directors, like riderless horses.   That has been the trend in recent years. The reasons are complex, having to do with Hollywood’s shifting economic model, but they boil down to basic maths. While the number of Oscars to hand out remains constant (24), the number of potential films to chose from – which is to say, dramas with gravitas that score highly with critics and audiences – shrinks slightly every year, as Hollywood chases “Star Wars III” and “Spiderman 4”. Which means the Academy has had to hunt slightly further afield than they would normally like, whether that means going indie (“The Hurt Locker”), going genre (“The Departed”, “No Country for Old Men”), heading overseas (“The Artist”), or softening objections to arthouse neobrutalism in the name of a good cause (“12 Years a Slave”).  None of those winners is what you might call a typical “Oscar movie”. It’s not because the Academy has gotten hipper. This year’s controversy over the whiteness of the Oscars, which resulted in a promise by the Academy’s president to rejuvenate membership, only told us what we already know: that the preponderance of the Academy’s 6,000 members are white, male and over 60. If someone were to make “Gandhi” today they would be all over it in a second. Hence the forces of fogeyishnes that propelled “The King’s Speech” and “Argo” to their wins. The preferential ballot favours consensus choices over polarisers: it’s not enough to be the number-one pick of a group of passionate supporters, you must also collect enough number-two and number-three picks on everybody else’s ballot.  The brutality of “The Revenant” is the sticking point here. Traditionally viscera cuts against gravitas, although again, Best Picture winners like “The Departed” and “12 Years a Slave” have loosened the Academy up a little. They owed Scorsese “The Departed”, and “12 Years A Slave” had the historical weight of its subject matter. Is the fact that “The Revenant” is a Western, like “No Country”, sufficiently reassuring? If not then the field is open for either “The Big Short” or “Spotlight”, our original front-runner. “The Big Short” won big at the PGAs, which has predicted the eventual Best Picture winner all eight times that it has voted since adopting the same preferential ballot as the Oscars. It’s not hard to see why this film, about a band of unlikely renegades betting against the money markets, was popular with producers: that’s a pretty good description of their job. But the film’s blackly satirical, snarky tone slightly thwarts the gravitas requirements. The Academy wants its moral lessons served up in neater, squarer boxes.  Which is where “Spotlight” comes in. For some critics, myself included, Tom McCarthy’s film is scrupulous but a little underdeveloped dramatically: we never felt the Church’s wrath. The sleeping giant never awoke.  But there’s no denying the power of its victims’ testimonials. Of all the contenders, “Spotlight” has the warmest emotional current. The only problem is that it looks set to win only one other Oscar, for Best Original Screenplay, which would make it the lowest-yield Best Picture winner in history. Is Hollywood ready for this, the anti-sweep? At this stage, I have “The Revenant” ahead by a nose, but check back on the 25th for my final predictions in all 24 categories.

Seems more likely this update cuts my losses than helps me win outright, but it was fun reading through 538's various models and modelers.

I base my forecast on 538's analysis: http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/oscars-2016/ Their methodology is really cool. Read further here: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/fivethirtyeights-guide-to-predicting-the-oscars/ and here https://fivethirtyeight.com/datalab/how-fivethirtyeights-oscar-predictions-did/  on the predictability of past insider awards (DGA, PGA, BAFTA, SAG, ACE and WGA) I am assuming that the the most predictive insider awards are DGA, PGA, BAFTA, SAG, ACE and  WGA. I include non-insider awards like the Golden Globes and Chicago Critics in the the overall 538 rating. The reason I do that (and following 538's lead) is that many members of the insiders guilds and associations are also members of the Academy and vote for both the Academy and their trade associations. So according to this analysis I am making the following forecasts: - 0% to all movies except REV, SHORT and SPOT for the following reasons:
      REV won the DGA and BAFTA (the first and the third most predictive awards according to 538) 
      REV is the top rated on 538 rating  
      SPOT is the second most rated on 538 and won the WGA and SAG awards (both with a predictive power of 40%) 
      SHORT is the third most rated on 538 and won the PGA award (the second most predictive award according to 538)  - 80% to REV because 
      REV won the DGA and BAFTA (the first and the third most predictive awards according to 538) 
      REV is the top rated overall on 538 rating   - 10% to SHORT because
      SHORT is the third most rated on 538 and 
      SHORT won the PGA award (the second most predictive award according to 538)  - 10% to SPOT 
    SPOT is the second most rated overall on 538 
    SPOT won the WGA and SAG awards (both with a predictive power of 40%)

Zeroing out SHORT.
Upping SPOT from 1 to 6.
(Big money still on REV to make up for having at 0 for most of this IFP). Feb 18: "Do Your Oscar Predictions Stack Up? Here’s What The Data Says" --> http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/oscar-data-model-predictions-2015/ The best picture race has been a doozy: “Mad Max: Fury Road” got off to a strong start in our model, dueling with “Spotlight” in the early part of January. Then “Spotlight” began to pull ahead, only to fall behind “The Big Short” after the highly predictive Producers Guild awards. Once the Screen Actors Guild awards had been announced, however, the two films were neck and neck — until “The Revenant” pulled off huge wins at the Directors Guild and BAFTAs, the awards from the British Academy. On @Grok's suggestion, I'm updating on my previous forecast (1) to account for The Revenant winning the BAFTA best picture. Over the last 20 years (The timescale I've been using for the other award-based indicators), the BAFTA best picture has gone on to win the Oscar 9 times. This isn't a great indicator, but it's much better than the 20% we'd expect if they were unrelated. I'm eyeballing that this is statistically significant, so we'll go with it.  I'm also going to weight the BAFTA a little bit higher, because 4 of the 11 movies that won the BAFTA best picture but failed to win the Oscar were British (Four Weddings and a Funeral, the Full Monty, The Queen, Atonement), and I'm guessing that the BAFTA's are *slightly* biased towards British entries. Thus, since The Revenant is not British, I think the BAFTAs are slightly better indicator of its Oscars success than if it were. So I'll say that the BAFTAs have 50% accuracy, which is pretty significant. For no good reason I'll say that the combined accuracy of BAFTA and DGA is 90%. This gives me 35% on Revenant, 28% on Spotlight, and 32% on The Big Short. I'll bump down Revenant 4% because  Iñárritu won last year, and then I'll bump it up like 6% because it's been nominated for shitloads of other categories, finally giving the probabilities I've assigned. DISCLAIMER: This is actually a really lazy and inconsistent way of assigning probabilities, FYI. It beats running on intuitions about how much you think Academy voters like finance films, but it's not great. It'd be awesome if anyone could refine this for me. So here's a summary of the most convincing evidence I've seen:
- The Big Short won the PGA, which predicts the Oscar for best picture 70% of the time. However, as @gleald points out, since the PGA changed its voting method to that of the Oscars, it has had 100% accuracy - so I'll weight the past 7 years more highly and put its accuracy at 85%. - Spotlight won the Critic's Choice Movie Awards, which predicts about 60% of the time, and the SAG outstanding cast award, which predicts 50% of the time. We'll put this as a combined indicator with 70% accuracy. - The Revenant won the DGA, which predicts 81% of the time. - Iñárritu's film Birdman won best picture last year, and I'm told that it's unlikely that he will win it twice in a row. We'll reduce the above 81% to 70% for this reason. - Over the last 20 years, Braveheart was the only film to win Best Picture but failed to win the DGA, SAG, CCA, or the PGA, so we'll put the base rate at 5% for the films that aren't the top 3. So we'll put the remaining films at 1% each. I really can't be assed sticking this all into Bayes Theorem, so I'll calculate the remaining 95% as a weighted sum of the likelihood given by our indicators, which gives us 34% on The Big Short, and 31% on both The Revenant and Spotlight, adjusted for rounding. Gross.

A good indicator is the usual buzz at film festivals (Toronto, Sundance, Berlin) but I didn't attend this year. So, here is what I'm looking at:
-SPOLIGHT won the Screen Actors Guild Award and the Critics Choice.  
-THE BIG SHORT won the Producer's Guild (which some times has gone along with the Academy when the DGA has deviated).  
-MAD MAX is still the critic's darling (included in many top 10 lists) but it wasn't nominated for best film at BAFTA which takes away points since, in recent years, they tend to go along with the Academy, at least in nominations.  
-THE REVENANT'S weakest point is the script (one major category in which it didn't get a nom). 
-SPOTLIGHT has the best shot to get the award for best original script, and likewise, The BIG SHORT has the edge for best adapted screenplay.  
-SPOTLIGHT, overall, is superbly crafted and carries a heavy moral weight.  The film's script should satisfy the Academy intellectually and emotionally. I don't want to get into criticism here but the film reaches very far in terms of society and something the Academy loves "the human experience."  But is this topic in now or would the Hollywood elite have a more pressing issue in mind to push?  That matters. 
-MAD MAX has a female lead in a year where gender equality is one of the most talked about issues and that gives it points. This film got 10 noms overall, only second to REVENANT.  Production design of the film and a lot of technical aspects give it a lot of points as well.  
- As for the BIG SHORT, there is a big demand for tv shows, docs and films about the financial crisis. It has one of the best scripts of the year and in many ways it's a difficult film to make well.   
- The REVENANT is by all measures a directorial feat and has the most noms of all this year, 12, but I have doubts about its overall depth or its transcendence beyond the look at its main character.  I'm not sure we can tell all that much about humanity just by looking at Glass. Nature is the protagonist in the film and in many ways it can serve as a great metaphor. I still have doubts about the clarity of it's depth and frankly, unrelenting suffering can get a little tiring. Of them all, this ss the most difficult movie to make but a lot of people say they don't vote for a film based on that. 
-The DGA is traditionally the best predictor for the Academy Award (it's as old as the Oscars and I think it has only picked a different film 13 times) but in those years where it has picked a different film, the Producer's Guild has sided with the Oscar pick. 
It is notable that the SAG is the largest branch of the Academy yet their record in predicting best picture is not great (this could be because they give award to actors individually and then to a film's cast ensemble). 
The Golden Globes are not as good predictors as the DGA. 
With that in mind, and pending the BAFTA on Feb 14, I am giving Spotlight the edge for best pic.  It only got 6 nom overall, just like Big Short, while the Revenant got 12 but I think that is because of the types of films that they are.

Difficult to know what to do. In the past 12 years, the winner of the PGA Award for Outstanding Producer of a Theatrical Motion Picture has predicted the Oscar winner for Best Picture 9 times. That would be "The Big Short" this year. The three exceptions were "The Aviator", which lost to "Million Dollar Baby" in 2004;  "Brokeback Mountain", which lost to "Crash" in 2005; and "Little Miss Sunshine", which lost to "The Departed" in 2006. "Million Dollar Baby" and "Crash" could be considered left-leaning "issues" films, which are popular with the Academy. This is hopeful for "Spotlight" this year, as it's an "issue" movie. "The Departed" is a gangster movie starring two Hollywood favorites -Leonardo di Caprio and Jack Nicholson- and directed by Martin Scorsese, another darling of the older Hollywood set. This is very similar to "The Revenant" this year, a Western directed by Alejandro Inarritu and starring di Caprio (who received the SAG award for Best Actor for both films). Notably, there was no "issues" film nominated the year "The Departed" won. I'm not sure what this means -except that either "The Revenant" or "Spotlight" could supplant "The Big Short". The producers branch of the Academy can't carry it alone. Does it mean that "Spotlight" is more likely to win than "The Revenant"? I think so, but the #2 choice of the Academy voters will determine the winner, if no film gets 50% of the vote on the first ballot. So the real question is which film is likely to get the most second place votes. The three films mentioned above will presumably survive several rounds of elimination. "The Big Short" is a comedy and a finance movie, which historically count against. "The Revenant" has made by far the most money, so more Academy voters will have seen it. "Spotlight" is the issues movie.

FYI, this is the voting procedure for Best Picture, from http://www.goldderby.com/cms/view/209/: "Unlike the winners of the other categories which are determined by popular vote -- i.e, a voter picks just one of the nominees and the Oscar goes to the that nominee with the most votes -- the winner of Best Picture is arrived at by a more complicated system. The academy uses preferential voting, as it does to determine nominees in most other races, to determine the winner of Best Picture. This method of voting was reintroduced in 2009, when the academy went to 10 Best Picture nominees for the first time since 1943 and was kept it in place in 2010 when the number of nominees was to be somewhere between five and 10. The academy believes this "best allows the collective judgment of all voting members to be most accurately represented." The preferential method was first used in 1934 when there were 12 Best Picture nominees (there had been between three and 10 in the first six years of the Academy Awards) and was used the following year when there were again 12 nominees, from 1936 to 1943 when there were 10 nominees, and in both 1944 and 1945 when there were just five contenders.  Voters rank the Best Picture nominees. If one nominee garners more than 50% of the first place votes, it will win Best Picture.  If, as is more likely, no nominee reaches this threshold, the film with the fewest first place votes is eliminated, with its ballots being reapportioned to the second place choice.  Should no film cross the required 50% + one ballot threshold, the film with the fewest first place votes is again elminated, with its ballots being apportioned to the next choice still in play (i.e., if the second place choice is no longer in the running, then the ballot would be reapportioned to the third place choice and so on.) This process of elimination and reapportion continues until one film reaches at least 50% + one ballots. That is the Best Picture winner."

Rationale in order from least to most likely: Room - apparently a great film, haven't seen it yet, but seems too small... also an indie (if that counts for anything) - will update this after I've seen it Bridge of Spies - haven't heard much aside from "go see it," some of its aggregate reviews are considerably low for it to win (Meteoritic @ 81%, IMDB @ 7.7/10...) that being said I won't count it out until I've seen it Mad Max: Fury Road - this is the film I'd most like to win Best Picture, but I think it came out too long ago and its competitors are fresher in the eyes of the public and most importantly the Academy, nonetheless if there is a dark horse it has to be Mad Max Brooklyn - Haven't seen it yet, but it seems like a variation of a story I've heard before, and despite the film's purported elegance and grace I'd be surprised if diaspora turned love story (plus more) won Best Picture The Martian - Awesome movie, really enjoyed it in all aspects, but I have to say that this was one of those movies where I sat down knowing how it'd end, and this detracted from it. The Martian has a lower probability because of its predictability (on a strict, broadly defined plot basis, it is not very complex, sort of unfolds before you) and also because it is in the same vein as Gravity; I think the Academy seems reluctant to give the award to a space thriller.  Top 3: A Close Race The Big Short - I've seen it twice and I think it's a hugely important film for our generation. The film oscillates effortlessly between jubilation, humor and sadness, loss as it delineates the housing crash in 2008. Short's star studded cast embodies its charisma, attention to detail, and at times outlandish nature. This has been my favorite movie of the year so far, but I think its lack of real conflict and story arc could hurt its chances. This seems to be one of the films that is nominated for everything but could fall short. It's also technically a comedy, which could also hurt its chances at winning. Spotlight - Seeing it tomorrow but I've heard great things. Many respectable reviewers (NYTimes, WSJ, Rolling Stone) have given it rave reviews, with WSJ's Morgenstern calling it "the best film of the year." Spotlight seemingly has everything, a great cast, director, and compelling script that tells a story of truth and righteousness. Spotlight's thrilling nature will surely work in its favor.  The Revenant: Also saw this twice, the first time being front row at an advanced screening in December and the second in early January. I really love this film but I think it is at risk of being over-hyped. From its outset and even from the trailer viewers can determine that Leo will get his revenge. With this in mind it's obvious that this isn't necessarily what The Revenant is really about, instead it is important to consider themes like loss, family, and life/death in general. What Revenant has going for it is Leo's face (an automatic mass-hype generator), incredible production value (filmed in all natural light, very few special effects), an amazing supporting cast (I actually thought Hardy performed the best), and a director with a Midas touch. What it has going against it is the hype factor, that being that hype can rise fast and drop abruptly. I've also heard a lot of people say they didn't like the film or were bored by it. I was kind of bored the second time around as the epiphanic moments I had the first time I saw it were reminiscences rather than mental clicks. Revenant is the favorite right now, but I'd be kind of surprised to see the same director win Best Picture two years in a row. To counter, one must consider that the Golden Globes are always a good indicator, and this year The Revenant took best drama, director, and actor.  To Summarize:

Considering the currebt Cold War-style brinkmanship scenario of Spielberg's "Bridge of Spies" ($76.5 million box office since its release in October, 2015 according to Box Office Mojo info) should resonate with Academy voters more than retro Woodstein 2.0 "Spotlight"  that glorifies print media journalism in the nascent days of the internet ("Spotlight has grossed just $34 million worldwide according to Box  Office Mojo data as of 25 Jan 2016 with a release date of 6 Nov 2015). But "The Big Short" also based on some factual information) examining the Subprime Mortgage Bubble that touched off the 2007 global economic crisis, seems positioned to win best picture because it shows the power of Hollywood globally. The film has grossed $86 million over the past month, according to latest Box Office Mojo, $30 million. Also figuring in is that Goldman Sachs and JP Morgan have just agreed to pay billion of dollars in fines for their roles in the "pump and dump" schemes associated with the bubble.  More than the other films, "The Big Short" emphasizes the power of social media and the internet, which are keys to the future of Hollywood.  As for "Revenant" it has grossed $225 million worldwide since being released on Christmas Day 2015 (Box Office Mojo stats) which is the most impressive of the nominees. But it is all DeCaprio all the time, which should earn for him the best male actor Oscar, in my view. Considering the issues of race and gender surrounding this year's ceremony, from where I sit, The Big Short seems to be the right call.

Jan 26: "How Much Do We Need To Know To Predict The Oscars?" http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/how-much-do-we-need-to-know-to-predict-the-oscars/ “The Big Short” won the top prize at the Producers Guild Awards on Saturday, making it the new favorite in our model. Historically, the winner of that Producers Guild honor has gone on to win the Academy Award for best picture about 70 percent of the time. Even more importantly, many of the people who vote on it are also members of the Academy; that gives the Producers Guild prize extra predictive power. In our model, Oscar nominees receive points for being nominated for or winning other awards that historically predict the Oscars. The better a historical predictor a given award is, the more points it’s worth. With 30 percent of possible points remaining to be distributed, “The Big Short” has 19 percent of possible points, “Spotlight” has 14 percent and “The Revenant” has 11 percent. “The Big Short” now has the highest potential final score in the field, followed closely by “Spotlight.” It’s increasingly looking like a two-picture race, but it’s too early to count anyone out. ~~ It's worth looking at how things looked on Jan 22 (before the PGA Awards): http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/fivethirtyeights-guide-to-predicting-the-oscars/ This race is the most wide open. There are many preceding awards left to go, and the field is large (eight films), which makes it hard to pick a leader. This weekend’s Producers Guild of America awards ceremony should give us a little clarity; the guild’s award for best theatrical picture is the second-most-predictive award we follow for the best picture Oscar. At the moment, “Spotlight” leads the race with 14 percent of all possible points locked up. It is followed closely by “The Revenant” (11 percent of possible points) and “Mad Max: Fury Road” (10 points). “The Revenant” won the Golden Globe for best drama, but it’s important to keep in mind that despite the popularity of the Globes, the winner of that award matches up with the Academy’s choice only about half the time. “Mad Max: Fury Road” has benefited from lots of nominations, as well as wins from the Chicago Film Critics Association and the National Board of Review. Whether that success will carry through to the Producers Guild awards remains to be seen. All the awards that have been announced so far have been voted on by members of the press, and while that group does have an inside track on perceiving winners and a means of controlling the narrative, it does not vote on the Academy Awards. It’s worth noting, for instance, that “Boyhood” did very well among the press last year but “Birdman” won the best picture Oscar after thriving at the industry awards. “Spotlight” is ahead this year because it received the most nominations in the categories we track and thanks to its best picture win at the Critics’ Choice Movie Awards, which are by far the most predictive of any of the press awards. What to watch: This is where we’d greatly benefit from more data. Whichever film wins at the Producers Guild awards will pick up a quarter of the remaining points and will be guaranteed front-runner status until at least February. After that, the key event to watch will be the Directors Guild of America’s top award. Any film that sweeps those two will be a strong favorite for best picture through the rest of February. If two films split them, we’ll have a serious race on our hands. ~~~~ COMMENT: So -- "The Big Short" won the PGA Awards. The DGA Awards are on Feb 6th. I'm happy to stay "heavy" on The Big Short until those awards are handed out. If The Big Short wins there, then we can be pretty confident that's who'll win the Oscar. Based on Hollywood buzz and the need to honor Leo with Best Actor, The Revenant stands a very good chance.  The Spotlight is a smart, well made story.
betting that the Academy can't pass up the American twist on the classic "hero on a quest" trope.
I may be overthinking this, LOL.  One thing I'm certain of:  "Mad Max: Fury Road" won't win Best Picture.  Sci-fi films virtually never win, and if one does win this year, it will be "The Martian."
Tweaking it a little more;  no rule against that!

If Iñárritu hadn't won Best Picture last year for Birdman, I'd say The Revenant was the forerunner, giving how taxing the movie was to make. However, Spotlight may have a shot for it's great cast and weighty true story subject matter. Also, the Golden Globes best picture only tends to win the Oscar about 50% of the time & it appears Leonardo DiCaprio is favored to finally win his first Best Actor Oscar for The Revenant, so another film may have a shot at Best Picture. I'd give The Big Short and The Martian equal probability to win behind those two & Mad Max a slight chance. They will probably honor Room with Brie Larson winning best actress.
Upon further consideration, while I really do think "The Revenant" is the most likely winner (and the most deserving), the Academy often surprises us, so I've spread my numbers out a little more.
The Revenant has it all; hype, death, betrayal, love, Leonardo and, a vicious bear scene.

I'd probably give "The Revenant" about a 97 percent probability of victory, except for the fact that "Birdman" won Best Picture last year, and I'm a little concerned that the Academy may be reluctant to give the Best Picture award to two films directed by the same man in two successive years.  But I suspect "The Revenant" still gets it.

A quick Google search of the various betting markets seems to indicate that at this time The Big Short and Spotlight are trending up (at least they are number 1 and 2 (order depending on the site) and The Revenant is down. Going bold for The Big Short---a statement film that causes conversation outside of the theater.  I am going to regret getting into this one, but, what the heck... Somebody talk me down off the ledge please.  :)
